- Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248.raw_text: - Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) — foreseeability and proximate cause principles.
- Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248.proposition:
Leading Cases (general negligence and premises liability authorities relied upon in Massachusetts and beyond)
- Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) — foreseeability and proximate cause principles.
- Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248.case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
- Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248.support_reasoning: The opinion is a leading authority on foreseeability as a limitation on duty and liability in negligence, which is a core component of general negligence doctrine and is frequently cited nationwide, including in Massachusetts, for foreseeability and proximate cause principles. Cardozo’s analysis focuses on the relational nature of negligence and the need for reasonably foreseeable risk to the plaintiff, which fits the proposition that Palsgraf is a leading case on foreseeability and proximate cause in negligence and premises-type situations.
- Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248.relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… Negligence, like risk, is thus a term of relation. Negligence in the abstract, apart from things related, is surely not a tort… If the harm was not willful, he must show that the act as to him had possibilities of danger so many and apparent as to entitle him to be protected… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us.”
